Fig. 1 (a-b) FE of PbSACu/CP at different potential under CO2 + 300 ppm NO conditions; FE of catalysts in pure CO2 and CO2 + 300 ppm NO: (a-b) PbSACu/CP; (c-d) Cu/CP. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Faraday efficiency of PbSACu/CP and Cu/CP catalysts ECO2 RR under different NO contents: (a-b) PbSACu/CP; (c-d) Cu/CP. Fig 2 Fig. 3 PbSA100 Cu/CP catalyst under the conditions of high purity CO2 and 300 ppm NO content condition: (a) LSV curve; (b) i-t curve; (c) durability test diagram of PbSA100 Cu/CP under the condition of CO2 containing 300 ppm NO. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Optimized structure model of NO adsorption at different adsorption sites and Mulliken charge distribution of O and N atoms: (a, d) Cu (111); (b, e) Pb adsorption site on PbSACu; (c, f) Cu a site on PbSACu; (g) free energies of CO2 and NO. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Schematic diagram of electronic reduction paths of CO2 and NO: (a) CO2→formate; (b) CO2→CO; (c) NO→NH3. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Gibbs free energy step diagram of surface catalytic reduction path between Cu (111) and PbSACu: (a-c) reaction path of Cu (111): (a) NO→NH₃, (b) CO₂→formate, (c) CO₂→CO; (d-f) reaction path of PbSACu; (d) NO→NH₃, (e) CO₂→formate, (f) CO₂→CO. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Free energy diagram of different pathways and HCOOH before and after NH3* adsorption on Cu (111) and PbSACu: CO2 reduced to CO on (a) Cu (111), (b) PbSACu; CO2 reduced to HCOOH on (c) Cu (111), (d) PbSACu. Traditional industries with high carbon emissions are facing the critical challenge of carbon utilization. Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 (ECO2RR) to produce high value-added products is an effective strategy to achieve “carbon neutrality” and sustainable development. However, most of the research is carried out under high purity CO2, and NO impurities in industrial exhaust gases can interfere with catalyst performance. This study investigated the impacts of NO on the ECO2RR of the self-developed single-atom Pb-modified bimetallic Cu-based catalyst (PbSACu/CP), evaluated its anti-NO performance capability of PbSACu/CP, and further revealed the mechanism via density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The results showed that, the NO resistance of PbSACu/CP was improved by >50 % compared with Cu/CP, which effectively reduced the impact of NO. Pb doping made the center of d-band of catalyst move to the left, weakening the adsorption capacity of the active sites for NO and inhibiting the interference of NO on the CO2 reduction reaction. In addition, the catalyst reduced the sensitivity to NO reduction intermediates, and further enhanced its NO resistance. The aim of this study is to provide theoretical guidance for designing efficient and anti-impurity ECO2RR catalysts and advance the development of carbon cycle technology in traditional industries. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Utilization of CO2 CO2 catalytic reduction Anti-NO poisoning Pb doped catalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (ECO2RR) is a promising technology for converting CO2 into high-value chemicals (such as HCOOH, CO, C2H4, CH3OH, C2H5OH) [1–3] using renewable electricity, provides an important pathway for carbon resource recycling in high-emission industries such as cement, steel, and thermal power generation. It holds significant application value in the context of “dual carbon” goals [4–6]. However, CO2 captured from industrial exhaust gases is not pure; it typically contains impurities such as nitrogen oxides (NOx), with NO accounting for 90–95 % of NOx. These impurities significantly interfere with the performance of ECO2RR catalysts, severely restricting the industrialization of this technology [7]. In ECO2RR research, Cu-based catalysts are among the most promising due to their rich presence, cost-effectiveness, and remarkable activity, which have attracted much attention from researchers [8]. However, Cu-based catalysts suffer from the problem of low product selectivity, which leads to high costs for subsequent products separation and purification. Therefore, modifying Cu-based catalysts is crucial to endow them with high selectivity for a certain product [9]. It was found that the selectivity of Cu-based bimetallic catalyst is dominated by the properties of the second metal, so the alloy electrocatalysts formed by Cu and post-transition metals have attracted attention in improving formate selectivity [10,11]. Rational design of bimetallic Cu-based catalyst can not only regulate product selectivity through electronic interactions but also improve current density via Cu’s good conductivity, demonstrating comprehensive performance superior to monometallic catalysts. Our previous studies [12] showed that single atom Pb doped Cu (PbSACu/CP) catalysts display a Faraday Efficiency (FE) of >95 % for formate in high-purity CO2 atmospheres. The core mechanism is mainly due to the adjustment of the adsorption energy between HCOO* and COOH* by single atom doping of Pb, making the reaction more inclined towards the formation path of formate. However, the previous studies were all carried out under high-purity CO2 [13]. At present, the toxic effect of NO x on the catalytic system is still not clear, which seriously restricts the application of ECO2RR in industry. Previous studies showed that when 200 ppm NO was introduced into the system, the overpotential of ECO2RR of Cu catalyst increased by 120 mV, and the selectivity of formate decreased by 63 % [14]. In addition, when the NO concentration was greater than 1667 ppm, the efficiency of the Cu catalyst for ECO2RR dropped significantly as the pH level decreased [15]. These issues pose significant challenges to the application of Cu-based catalysts in actual industrial environments. Currently, research on NO interference in ECO2RR remains insufficient. Existing reports mostly focus on monometallic Cu catalysts, with little attention paid to bimetallic systems, especially high-performance formate-selective catalysts like Pb-doped Cu, and their anti-NO interference mechanisms are still unclear. Specifically, key scientific questions such as how NO effects the electronic structure of bimetallic sites, whether it changes the rate-determining step of the formate generation pathway, and whether Pb doping can inhibit NO competition by regulating the adsorption energy of active sites, all lack systematic research. Based on this, and in light of the characteristics of exhaust gas from the cement industry, this study investigated the effects of different concentrations of NO on the ECO2RR performance of the previously reported single-atom Pb-doped Cu-based catalyst (PbSACu/CP) [12]. Through density functional theory (DFT) calculation, the competitive adsorption rules of NO and CO2 at bimetallic sites was clarified, and the mechanism of electronic regulation of Pb doping on enhancing NO poisoning resistance was revealed. This study can not only provide new insights into the rational design of the active center of catalyst, but also provide a theoretical basis for the development of high-efficiency ECO2RR catalyst suitable for the exhaust gas of industry, which helps to promote the “carbon cycle” and “carbon utilization” technology in the high-CO2 emission industries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation In our previous studies, a three-dimensional Cu-based catalyst doped with Pb single atoms was directly prepared on carbon paper (PbSACu/CP). For the specific preparation method, refer to our previous research [12]. Briefly, the preparation process consists of two steps. The first step was to prepare Cu2O: 100 mM anhydrous cupric sulfate and 800 mM C3H6O3 were dissolved in water, and then the pH of the solution was adjusted to 12 using NaOH solution, and the obtained solution was used as electrolyte. 100 mL of the above electrolyte was placed in a water bath at 60 °C and stirred. Carbon paper served as the anode, a graphite sheet as the cathode electrode, current density was set at 3 mA∙cm⁻², and the electrodeposition lasted for 1 hour. The second step was: Pb single atom doping by cyclic voltammetry: used 100 mL solution containing 1 M KOH and 100 μM Pb(NO3)2 as electrolyte. Taken the prepared Cu2O/CP as the working electrode, a graphite sheet as the counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) as the reference electrode. Voltage scanning was conducted at a rate of 50 mV/s for 600 cycles. Then, a constant voltage of –0.9 V was applied for 30 min. The preparation method of comparative sample Cu/CP was similar to that of PbSACu/CP, except that Pb(NO3)2 was not added in the cyclic voltammetry step. 2.2 Measurements The tests were conducted at room temperature using a closed H-type electrolytic cell. The platinum sheet served as the counter electrode, the Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode, and the catalyst functioned as the working electrode. A proton exchange membrane separated the anode and cathode chambers of the electrolytic cell. Each chamber was filled with 30 mL of 0.5 M aqueous KHCO₃ solution, which was utilized as the electrolyte. Potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to the following Eq. (1) [13,16]: (1) E RHE = E Ag / AgCl + 0.199 + 0.059 × pH here E Ag/AgCl denotes the potential detected during the experiment. NO x content in industrial exhaust gas can be categorized into three stages. The first stage corresponds to the initial NO x content of before denitrification treatment (1000 mg/m3 [17]). The second stage refers to the NO x content meeting national standards after denitrification (≤400 mg/m3, ∼300 ppm [18]). The third stage represents the NO x content in CO2 after typical amine-based capture (<50 ppm). Among NO x pollutants, NO dominates (90–95 %), with NO2 accounting for 5–10 %. In this study, three concentrations (50 ppm, 300 ppm, and 1000 ppm) were selected to investigate the influence of NO on the performance of the catalyst for CO2 reduction. To obtain the required gas components, a high-precision gas supply system with an automated gas mixer which contain a gas controller (MCQ-6000, e.g., MCQ Instrument T6000 series) was used to achieve target NO concentrations. Specifically, 50 ppm NO was generated by mixing 100 ppm NO/CO2 (commercially procured) with high-purity CO2 at a 1:1 vol ratio (12.5 mL/min each, total 25 mL/min); 300 ppm NO was prepared by blending 1000 ppm NO/CO2 with high-purity CO2 at a 3:7 ratio (7.5 mL/min and 17.5 mL/min, total 25 mL/min); and 1000 ppm NO directly used the commercially procured 1000 ppm NO/CO2 gas at 25 mL/min. Directly used the commercially procured 1000 ppm NO/CO2 gas at a flow rate of 25 mL/min. The mixed gas was introduced into the electrolytic cell at 25 mL/min via flow rate regulation by the gas mixing controller. gas mixing controller was used to regulate the flow rate of each gas; after mixing, the mixture was introduced into the electrolytic cell at a flow rate of 25 mL/min. To ensure accuracy, the system was calibrated weekly using purchased standard gases (100 ppm and 1000 ppm NO/CO2), with zero calibration via high-purity CO2 purging (NO < 0.5 ppm). Additionally, a Kin-Tek Span Pac I device was used to test NO content prior to each experiment. The liquid products were analyzed by 1H NMR spectrometer (Bruker Advance III 400 HD) using dimethyl sulfoxide as the internal standard. 800 μL of the electrolyte was withdrawn and then combined with 0.1 mL of deuterium oxide and 0.1 mL of 0.01 M dimethyl sulfoxide. Gas products were collected and analyzed using gas chromatography (GC, SHIMADZU, 2021pro). The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of the products was determined using the subsequent equations: (2) F E ( liquid ) ( % ) = Q X Q t o t a l = n x N x F Q t o t a l (3) F E ( gas ) ( % ) = Q X Q t o t a l = m x 24000 c m 3 / m o l v t N x F Q t o t a l In these equations, Qx denotes the charge needed to generate a particular product (x). On the other hand, Qtotal represents the overall charge consumed throughout the ECO2RR process. nx stands for the quantity (in moles) of product x. Nx indicates the number of electrons essential for the formation of the certain substance x. mx represents the measured concentration of the gaseous products. V represents the gas flow rate at the outlet, which is determined using a soap film flowmeter. t is the reaction duration, and F stands for Faraday constant, having a value of 96,485 C mol–1. 2.3 Computation method All the calculations in this study were completed by Materials Studio Dmol3 module. The exchange-correlation interaction was described using the PBE functional within the GGA [19]. Literature reports indicate that the Cu (111) crystal plane has the lowest surface energy and is thus the most stable [20]. Therefore, a 4 × 4 periodic model was constructed using the Cu (111) plane for the pure Cu structure model. In order to avoid the interaction in the periodic system, a vacuum layer of 15 Å was added between the layers. At the same time, the potential is introduced in the direction of C axis to eliminate the non-zero dipole moment caused by polar adsorbates in the periodic model. PbSACu model was built by substituting one Cu atom in the Cu (111) with a Pb atom. The atoms in the bottom two layers of slab model were fixed during optimization, while those in the top layer were fully relaxed. To ensure the accuracy and reliability of the calculation results, all initial parameters undergone strict convergence tests [21]. Chemical adsorption energies were calculated using Eq. (4) [22]. A negative E ads indicates an exothermic adsorption, with a larger absolute value corresponding to a more exothermic process. (4) E ads = E surface − iso − ( E surface + E iso ) Where, E surface-isorepresents the system energy when molecules are adsorbed on the model surface; E surf is the energy of the structural model; E isois the energy of adsorbed molecules. The model for calculating the hydrogen electrode (CHE) is shown by Nørskov et al. [23]. When an external potential is applied, the chemical potential of the proton-electron pair will decrease by a certain amount of eU to keep the balance, as shown in Eq. (5): (5) H + + e − = 1 / 2 H 2 − eU + k B Tln 10 × pH The change of Gibbs free energy (ΔG) calculated by CHE model is obtained according to equation Eq. (6): (6) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G pH + G U where, ΔE H and ΔE ZPE are represent the alterations in total energy, zero-point energy and entropy. TΔS represents the entropic contributions (T = 298.2 K). ΔG pH denotes the free-energy correction resulting from the change in H + concentration, which is calculated by equation Eq. (7): (7) Δ G pH = − k B Tln 10 × pH where G U represents the influence of electrode potential (U), and G U=−eU. This study is based on the assumption that the solution pH = 0 and U is 0 [24]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of NO on catalyst performance Firstly, the PbSACu/CP catalyst was tested under CO2 + 300 ppm NO over a series potential, which results as shown in Fig. 1(a, b). These results indicate that formate is the dominant product within the range of −0.7 to −1.0 V vs. RHE. Specifically, FEformate increases with increasingly negative potential, reaching a maximum of 82 % at −0.9 V, and then slightly decreasing to 78 % at −1.0 V. This change trend of FEformate is very similar to that observed in pure CO2 [12], indicating that Pb-doped catalysts maintain consistent formate selectivity even in the absence of NO. In addition, the total FE for CO2 reduction exhibits negligible fluctuation across different potentials, indicating that the competitive reduction between NO and CO2 is not sensitive to the applied potential within this window. Subsequent tests were therefore carried out at −0.9 V (vs. RHE). Fig. 1(c-f) shows the comparison of the ECO2RR performance of PbSACu/CP and Cu/CP catalysts under pure CO2 and 300 ppm NO-containing atmospheres. As shown in Fig. 1(c, d), PbSACu/CP exhibited high FE for formate (FEformate>95 %) under pure CO2 conditions. Upon introducing 300 ppm NO into the electrolysis system at t = 2 h, the total FE (FEtotal) of PbSACu/CP decreased by 11.1 %, with FEformate dropping by 15.7 % and multi-carbon (C2+) products (ethylene, ethanol, acetate) FE declining by 7.2 %. Although the selectivity of PbSACu/CP for formate decreased significantly, formate was still the main reduction product, with FEformate staying above 80 %. In contrast, Cu/CP experienced a 22.5 % loss in FEtotal under NO exposure. FE of C2+decreased from 33.0 % to 24.2 % (a 35.2 % drop), and FEformate decreased from 34.3 % to 22.2 % (a 26.7 % drop). Meanwhile, the hydrogen evolution reaction was significantly enhanced, indicating that NO had a more pronounced impact on the performance of pure Cu compared with PbSACu/CP catalyst. Assuming complete conversion of NO to NH3, the FE of NO conversion of PbSACu/CP and Cu/CP was 11.1 % and 22.5 %, respectively. Notably, when the atmosphere was switched back to pure CO2, the FEtotal and product distribution of both catalysts quickly returned to initial levels and remained stable during the subsequent 2 h of electrolysis (Fig. 1 e, f). This phenomenon indicates that the decline in catalyst performance caused by NO primarily from a reversible competitive adsorption mechanism rather than irreversible catalyst poisoning. Fig. 2 presents a comparative analysis of how different NO concentrations affect the ECO2RR performance of PbSACu/CP and Cu/CP catalysts. Experimental results show that as NO concentration increases from 0 ppm to 1000 ppm, the total FE of CO2 reduction over PbSACu/CP exhibits a gradual decreasing trend (Fig. 2 a). At 50 ppm NO, the total FE decreases only slightly by 1.5 %, with an almost negligible effect. However, when NO concentration rises to 1000 ppm, the total FE drops to 82.6 %, a decrease of 18.3 %. Among these, the FE of formate and C2+ decreased by 21.7 % and 7.8 % respectively (Fig. 2 b). In contrast, the Cu/CP catalyst is more sensitive to NO (Fig. 2 c, d). At 1000 ppm NO, its total FE decreases by 32 %, with the FE of formate dropping by 39.2 % and C2+ FE decreasing by 42.5 %. This disparity indicates that Pb doping reduced the impact of NO on the performance of Cu-based catalysts. The impact of NO on the total FE was reduced by 40 %−50 %, and the negative impact on the FE of formate was reduced by 55.4 % (Table 1 ). The decrease in ECO2RR FE may be due to the competitive adsorption of NO and CO2 at active sites, where NO occupies some of these active sites. In addition, NO reduction takes precedence over CO2 reduction, interfering with the formation and stabilization of CO2 intermediates. This difference may be that Pb regulated the electronic properties of the Cu active sites, inhibiting the competitive reduction reaction of NO, thus alleviating the interference of NO with CO2 reduction. The detailed verification will be provided in subsequent DFT theoretical calculations. The linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) (Fig. 3 a) and i-t curves (Fig. 3 b) of PbSACu/CP demonstrate that the cathodic current density (absolute value) is higher for the CO2 + 300 ppm NO system compared to pure CO2. This current density increased may due to three reasons: (1) NO exhibits stronger preferential adsorption and higher reduction activity on the catalyst surface compared to CO2 [25]; (2) the adsorption of NO may lower the reaction energy barrier, facilitate the reaction process, and enhance the reduction current density [26]; and (3) NO reduction involves more electrons per molecule than CO2 reduction to formate [27]. Meanwhile, the durability of PbSACu/CP under the gas conditions containing NO was evaluated at a constant potential of −0.9 V (vs. RHE). The results showed that the catalyst exhibit good stability during the reaction process lasting 12 h. The current density did not increase significantly, and the FE of formate remained above 80 % throughout (Fig. 3 c). In addition, the pH value was test during the durability process (Fig. S1). The result show that the electrolyte pH remained stable within the range of 7.0–7.8 over 13 h of reaction. 3.2 Adsorption behavior of NO on catalyst surface To deeply analyze the competitive adsorption mechanism of NO and CO2 on the catalyst surface, the adsorption differences of NO and CO2 on Cu (111) and PbSACu surfaces were compared and analyzed, and the regulation mechanism of Pb single atom doping on competitive adsorption was clarified. The PbSACu catalyst contains two distinct active sites: Type A (Cu sites, PbSACu-Cu), which is Cu atom in the vicinity of the Pb single atom, retaining a similar local coordination environment to Cu (111) but modified by the electronic effect of Pb; and Type B (Pb sites, PbSACu-Pb), which is Pb single atom replaces a Cu atom in the Cu (111) lattice, creating a unique coordination environment. Structural optimization (Fig. 4 a–f) revealed distinct adsorption modes. On Cu (111) and Type A (PbSACu-Cu), NO adopted a vertical N-down configuration within the triangular Cu vacancy, forming a four-coordinated planar structure. In contrast, when NO adsorbed on Type B (PbSACu-Pb), it exhibited a tilted geometry (with an N–O bond angle of 120°) with N–Pb coordination. This divergence indicated site-specific electronic modulation of adsorption orientation. Adsorption energy calculations (Fig. 4 g ) revealed NO had a stronger binding affinity than CO2 on both Cu (111) (E ads =−0.48 eV vs. −0.42 eV) and A type (E ads =−0.4 eV vs. −0.38 eV). This thermodynamic preference accounted for the competitive inhibition of CO2 reduction by NO, as it occupied the active sites. Notably, NO adsorption at Type B required endothermic energy (+0.17 eV), which was significantly higher than the adsorption energy of CO2 at this site. Pb doping thus suppressed NO adsorption by redistributing surface sites. As summarized in Table 2 , the Cu–N bond length of adsorbed NO on the Cu (111) surface was measured to be 2.04 Å, corresponding to the strongest adsorption strength. Notably, in the PbSACu system, bond lengths increased to 2.12 Å (Type A) and 2.64 Å (Type B), confirming progressively weaker adsorption stability. This trend directly correlated with N–O bond activation: while free NO exhibited an N–O bond length of 1.17 Å, adsorption on Cu (111), Type A, and Type B extended it to 1.22 Å, 1.21 Å, and 1.17 Å, respectively, consistent with the bond elongation–adsorption strength relationship. The adsorption relationship between catalyst surface and adsorbed molecules is determined by the electron density distribution between them. The Mulliken charge distribution can directly show the gain and loss electron relationship between the surface of catalytic materials and adsorbed molecules. After NO adsorption, the atomic charge of active site on Cu (111) increased from −0.021 e to 0.261 e, and the net electron loss reached 0.282 e, which was significantly higher than those of Type A (0.23 e) and Type B (0.147 e) of PbSACu systems. In addition, after NO was adsorbed on Cu (111), Type A and Type B, the overall charge amount decreased from 0 in the free state to −0.296 e, −0.281e and −0.105 e, respectively. According to the donor-acceptor mechanism (higher Mulliken charge value means stronger bond between donor and acceptor) [28], the higher electron transfer amount on the surface of Cu (111) enhances the strength of metal-adsorbate physicochemical bond, which further proved that Cu (111) has stronger adsorption of NO than that of both Type A and Type B of PbSACu system, and the adsorption of NO on Type A was more stable than that on Type B of PbSACu system. Therefore, all subsequent studies were carried out based on the Type A of PbSACu. 3.3 Competition between NO and CO2 reduction paths According to the research by Long et al. [29], NO molecules are more likely to form NH3 on the surface of Cu-based catalysts. The proposed NO reduction (NORR) and CO2 reduction pathways are illustrated in Fig. 5 . To quantify the competition between NORR and ECO2RR, the adsorption free energies of the key NORR intermediates (NHO*, N*, NH*, NH2*) on the surfaces of Cu (111) and PbSACu were systematically calculated (Fig. S2), compared them with CO2 reduction pathways (formate and CO/C2+ generation) (Fig. 6 ). The results show that on Cu (111), the rate-determining step (RDS) for NORR (NO + H⁺ + e⁻ → NOH*) exhibited a Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) of 0.42 eV, which is 0.58 eV lower than that of the CO2-to-formate RDS (CO2 + H⁺ + e⁻ → HCOO*, ΔG = 1.0 eV). This significant thermodynamic advantage enabled NO molecules to preferentially occupy the active sites, reducing the occupancy of effective active sites in the formate formation pathway. This was consistent with the observed decrease in the FE of formate in the experiment. Notably, Pb single-atom doping effectively alleviated this competition by tuning energy barrier distributions. On the surface of PbSACu, the energy barrier of the RDS of NO increased to 0.48 eV, and the energy barrier difference from the CO2 to formate pathway decreased to −0.04 eV, significantly reducing the competition of NO for active sites in the formate pathway. Therefore, the influence of NO reduction on CO2 to formate conversion over PbSACu was relatively weak, and this was not the main factor causing the decrease in formate FE. For CO/C2+pathways, NORR on Cu (111) showed a 0.06 eV lower RDS barrier compared to that for CO/C2+ generation. This difference increased to 0.3 eV for PbSACu. However, the inherently high energy barrier for COOH* intermediate formation on PbSACu (0.72 eV) limited CO/C2+generation, rendering NORR’s impact negligible. Comparative pathway analysis further revealed that Pb doping mitigated NO’s interference by preferentially destabilizing NORR over CO2 reduction. 3.4 Effect of NO and NH3 adsorption on ECO2RR path Since the reactant (NO) and product (NH3) exhibited stable adsorption, their influence on the performance of ECO2RR was investigated. The most stable configurations of NO* and NH3* adsorbed on the catalyst surface are shown in Fig. S3. The optimized structures of COOH*, CO*, and HCOO* after the adsorption of NO* and NH3* on the catalyst are shown in and Fig. S4. Fig. 7 shows the comparison of the ΔG of CO2 reduction to CO/C2+ and formate on the surfaces of Cu (111) and PbSACu, both before and after NH3*adsorption. For CO/C2+ pathways, the reaction CO2 + H⁺ + e⁻ → COOH* remained the RDS on both catalysts, with energy barriers of 0.48 eV (Cu (111)) and 0.72 eV (PbSACu), respectively. After NH3* adsorption, the RDS of this pathway shifted to CO* desorption to form CO, with energy barriers increasing by 0.96 eV and 0.55 eV, respectively. This change demonstrated that NH3* adsorption affected CO formation on both catalysts. Meanwhile, adsorbed CO* had more opportunities to adsorb H⁺ to form CHO* or undergo CC coupling to generate C2+ products. Therefore, NH3* adsorption not only inhibited CO formation but also promoted C2+ formation. In the pathway of CO2 reduction to formate, after NH3* adsorption, the RDS for both Cu (111) and PbSACu remained unchanged, remaining as HCOO* + H⁺ + e⁻ → HCOOH +*, but the energy barriers increased by 0.72 eV and 0.46 eV, respectively. This result showed that NH3* adsorption inhibited the pathway of CO2 reduction to formate on both catalysts. However, compared with Cu (111), Pb doping significantly reduced the impact of NH3* on ECO2RR performance. Fig. 8 shows the influence of NO* adsorption on the CO2 reduction pathways of Cu (111) and PbSACu. This influence was mainly reflected in changes in the adsorption strength of the COOH* intermediate, but its regulatory effect on the energy barrier of the RDS energy barrier was relatively limited. For the CO generation pathway (Fig. 8 a, b), NO* adsorption shifted the RDS from CO2 + H⁺ + e⁻ → COOH* to CO desorption. Before NO* adsorption, the RDS energy barriers for Cu (111) and PbSACu were 0.48 eV and 0.72 eV, respectively; after NO* adsorption, they increased marginally to 0.50 eV (+0.02 eV) and remained unchanged at 0.72 eV, respectively. This negligible barrier changes suggested that NO* adsorption did not introduce significant kinetic obstacles and maintained the CO pathway activity. However, adsorbed CO* exhibited a stronger tendency of C–C coupling, which was beneficial for the production of C2+ products. In the formate pathway, the effect of NO* adsorption showed catalyst dependence. For Cu (111) (Fig. 8 c), the RDS barrier remained at 0.09 eV before and after NO* adsorption, indicating that NO* adsorption had almost no effect on the formate path of Cu (111). However, on PbSACu (Fig. 8 d), the RDS barrier increased by 0.20 eV (0.09 eV → 0.29 eV) due to the enhanced HCOO* adsorption, indicating that NO* adsorption selectively hindered formate formation on the Pb-doped surface. Projected density of states (PDOS) analysis, as shown in Fig. 9 a, revealed that the adsorption of NH3* led to a shift of the d-band center of Cu (111) from −2.43 eV to −2.36 eV and that of PbSACu from −2.59 eV to −2.53 eV, respectively. This positive shift indicated that the adsorption of NH3* enhanced the electron transfer ability between the d-orbital of metal atoms and the intermediates. As a result, it strengthened the adsorption of intermediates and elevated energy barriers for the RDS, thus inhibiting the activity of ECO2RR [30]. In contrast, NO* adsorption caused a smaller d-band center shift, and moderately increased intermediate adsorption without significantly change the kinetics of CO pathway. Mulliken charge distribution analysis shown in Fig. 9 b, further demonstrated that the adsorption of NH3* and NO* rendered the active sites of Cu (111) and PbSACu more negatively charged, with the influence of NH3* being more pronounced. This charge redistribution enhanced the electron-donating ability of the metal sites and improved the electron transfer efficiency between them and the adsorbed molecules, and thus enhanced the adsorption energy of the catalyst for the reaction intermediates at the thermodynamic level. 3.5 Effect of intermediate adsorption on ECO2RR Intermediate species (NOH*, N*, NH2*) generated during NO reduction may be adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, which can potentially affect the ECO2RR activity. To explore their mechanistic influences, the adsorption behaviors of these intermediates and their impacts on pathway selectivity were systematically analyzed. NOH* showed one stable adsorption configuration on Cu (111) surface, but two distinct configurations on the PbSACu surface (Fig. S5, Table S1). Compared with A type, the adsorption at B type showed lower adsorption energy and shorter N–Cu bond lengths. This observation demonstrated that NO was preferentially adsorbed on the active sites. The optimized models of Cu (111) and PbSACu for absorbing CO2 intermediates (COOH*, CO* and HCOO*) after adsorb NHO* was shown in Fig. S6. The energy barrier calculations (Fig. 10 ) demonstrated that the adsorption of NOH* on Cu (111) increased the RDS barrier for CO2-to-CO conversion (CO2 + H⁺ + e⁻ → COOH*) by 1.3 eV, which seriously inhibited the CO/C2+ pathway. In contrast, PbSACu exhibited altered RDS sequences (shifted to COOH* + H⁺ + e⁻ → CO* + H₂O), and the barrier increased by 0.19 eV. For the formate pathway, the adsorption of NOH* caused negligible barrier increments (0.078 eV on Cu (111), 0.049 eV on PbSACu), which proved its limited interference. PDOS analysis (Fig. 11 ) revealed that NOH* adsorption reduced the d-band center (εd) of Cu (111) and PbSACu from −2.43 eV and −2.59 eV to −2.75 eV (a shift of −0.32 eV) and −2.76 eV (a shift of −0.20 eV), respectively. This negative shift indicated that the hybridization between metal d-orbitals and COOH* antibonding orbitals was weakened [31], which in turn reduced the electron transfer capability and hindered the activity of ECO2RR [30]. Notably, PbSACu exhibited a smaller d-band center shift and a lower initial εd (−2.59 eV), which reduced the impact of NOH* on ECO2RR. Mulliken charge distribution analysis (Fig. 11 b) further demonstrated that the adsorption of NOH* increased the charge at active site of Cu (111) from −0.014 e to +0.006 e, which indicated that the electron loss and the electron donating ability decreased. These electron changes weakened the electron donor ability and COOH* adsorption, subsequently reduced the catalytic performance. The impacts of N*, NH*, and NH2* on ECO2RR were also investigated. The adsorption configurations of these intermediates and the subsequent CO2-ralated intermediates (COOH*, CO*, HCOO*) are shown in Figs. S8–S10. Gibbs free energy profiles (Fig. S11) revealed N* had a negligible influence on the CO or formate pathways. However, the adsorption of NH* on Cu (111) was stronger (Table S2). As indicated by the Mulliken charge distribution, a greater amount of electron transfer from Cu atoms to NH* was observed, stabilizing its adsorption. For the CO/C2+ pathway, the adsorption of NH* and NH2* shifted the RDS from CO2+H ++e −→COOH* to CO desorption. This change led to an increase in the RDS energy barriers by 0.48 eV on Cu (111) and 0.72 eV on PbSACu (Fig. S12, 13). This inhibition of CO formation was accompanied by an enhanced C–C coupling through the adsorbed CO*, thereby promoting the C2+ products. In the pathway of CO2 reduction to formate, although the RDS remained unchanged for both catalysts, the energy barriers significantly increased. This result showed that the adsorption of NH* also inhibited the ECO2RR pathway to formate over both catalysts, but compared with Cu (111), the adsorption of NH* had a slightly weaker effect on the formation of formate by PbSACu. Therefore, the adsorption of NH* and NH2*, was the main reason for the significant decrease of FE of Cu (111) and PbSACu for producing formate and CO. After NH* and NH2* are adsorbed on Cu (111) and PbSACu, the d band center of the active sites shifted positively (Fig. S14, 15). This phenomenon indicated that the adsorption of NH* and NH2* could adjust the distribution of the electronic state density of metal atoms, and enhance the adsorption strength of the catalyst towards reaction intermediates (COOH*, CO* and HCOO*). Consequently, the energy required for the desorption of CO* in the CO pathway and HCOO* in the formate pathway increased, inhibiting the ECO2RR. The Mulliken charge distribution analysis further revealed that the adsorption sites exhibited more negative charge characteristics after the adsorption of NH*. This charge redistribution effect significantly enhanced the electron donating capacity of the active site and the electron transfer efficiency between the active sites and the adsorbed molecules. Consequently, it increased the adsorption energy of the catalyst for the reaction intermediates from a thermodynamic level. The adsorption of intermediates NH* and NH2* resulted in the changes to the electronic structure of the active sites and directly led to the increase in the energy barrier of RDS in each pathway. Compared with the adsorption of NH*, the adsorption of NH2* had a more significant impact on ECO2RR. In contrast to the Cu (111) catalyst, the doping of Pb mitigated the influence of intermediate adsorption. In summary, the impact of intermediates generated during NO reduction on the selection of the CO2 reduction pathways is as follows: the adsorption of NOH* inhibited the pathways of CO2 reduction to CO and C2+ on Cu (111) surface. This inhibition was the main factor contributing to the decrease in the FE of CO and C2+ products on Cu (111). The adsorption of N* showed no effect on either catalyst. The adsorption of NH* and NH2* significantly inhibited the CO and formate reaction pathways during ECO2RR of both Cu (111) and PbSACu. However, it promoted the formation of C2+ products to a certain extent. Thus, this adsorption was the reason for the decrease in the FE of CO and formate in the products of CO2 reduction by Cu (111) and PbSACu. Notably, compared with Cu (111), the doping of Pb alleviated the impact on formate selectivity to a certain extent. 3.6 Mechanism of resisting NO poisoning Several factors affecting the selectivity of catalyst were comprehensively evaluated, where ↓ represents inhibition, ↑ stands for promotion and −−− stands for no influence. According to the intensity of influence, the factors were divided into three grades, which were indicated by the number of arrows. The evaluation is listed as follows (Table 3 ): For Cu (111), CO formation was significantly inhibited by multiple factors. Among these, NOH*, NH2* and NH3* were identified as primary causes for the reduced FE of CO. Notably that these factors have contradictory effects on the formation of C2+products. The adsorption of NOH* altered the electronic distribution of active sites, shifted the d band center to lower energy levels, weakened the adsorption of COOH* and CO*, increased the energy barrier of RDS, and thereby inhibited the formation of C2+. In contrast, the adsorption of NH*, NH2* and NH3*shifted the d band center to the right, which enhanced the adsorption of CO*, inhibited CO* desorption, and further significantly promoted CC coupling for C2+ generation. Meanwhile, the formate pathway over Cu (111) was mainly inhibited by two factors: the preferential reduction of NO, which occupied the active sites, and the increased RDS energy barrier caused by the adsorption of NH2* and NH3*. This dual inhibition led to a significant decrease in FE of formate. In contrast, the PbSACu catalyst exhibited remarkable anti-interference properties. Firstly, Pb doping mitigated the occupation of active sites by NO molecules, acting as a protective shield, as illustrated in Fig. 13 . Secondly, the sensitivity of the CO and formate pathways to the adsorption of NH*, NH2* and NH3* was significantly reduced. This was attributed to the electronic buffering effect of single atom Pb (characterized by a decrease shift amplitude of the d band center), which significantly weakened the interference with the ECO2RR pathways. Comprehensive analysis revealed that the selectivity of Cu (111) was easily affected by the competitive adsorption and reduction of NO, as well as the adsorption of NOH*, NH2* and NH3*. Conversely, PbSACu was only influenced by NH2* and NH3*, with the impact on product selectivity being greatly mitigated by the doping of Pb single atom. These findings not only provide a theoretical foundation for designing highly selective NO-resistant catalysts but also offere experimental and theoretical support for the application of such catalysts in industrial CO2 reduction production. 4 Conclusions In summary, regarding the poisoning problem of ECO2RR caused by NO impurities in the industrial exhaust gas, the anti-NO interference performance and mechanism of PbSACu/CP catalyst were systematically investigated. When 300 ppm NO was introduced into CO2, the total FE of the traditional Cu catalyst decreased by 22.5 %, with the FE of formate and C2+ decreased by 35.2 % and 26.7 % respectively. In contrast, when using self-prepared PbSACu/CP, the total FE only decreased by 11.1 %, and its anti-NO performance was improved by >50 %. DFT calculations revealed that the single-atom Pb doping shifted the d-band center of the catalyst to lower energy levels, weakening the adsorption capacity of active sites for NO and effectively inhibiting NO from occupying the active sites. Furthermore, the mechanism studies indicated that the adsorption of NH*, NH2*, and NH3* generated during NO reduction process was also a key factor affecting the formate selectivity of Cu-based catalysts. Compared with the traditional Cu catalysts, PbSACu/CP can significantly reduce the sensitivity to these adverse factors, thus providing an effective solution from the perspective of anti-NO poisoning mechanism. The findings of these in-depth studies provide a foundation for achieving the goals of “carbon peaking and carbon neutrality” in the field of high-CO2 emission industries. coredata.dc:description: Traditional industries with high carbon emissions are facing the critical challenge of carbon utilization. Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 (ECO2RR) to produce high value-added products is an effective strategy to achieve “carbon neutrality” and sustainable development. However, most of the research is carried out under high purity CO2, and NO impurities in industrial exhaust gases can interfere with catalyst performance. This study investigated the impacts of NO on the ECO2RR of the self-developed single-atom Pb-modified bimetallic Cu-based catalyst (PbSACu/CP), evaluated its anti-NO performance capability of PbSACu/CP, and further revealed the mechanism via density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The results showed that, the NO resistance of PbSACu/CP was improved by >50 % compared with Cu/CP, which effectively reduced the impact of NO. Pb doping made the center of d-band of catalyst move to the left, weakening the adsorption capacity of the active sites for NO and inhibiting the interference of NO on the CO2 reduction reaction. In addition, the catalyst reduced the sensitivity to NO reduction intermediates, and further enhanced its NO resistance. The aim of this study is to provide theoretical guidance for designing efficient and anti-impurity ECO2RR catalysts and advance the development of carbon cycle technology in traditional industries.
